abstract.p: Parendozoicomonas haliclonae gen. nov. sp. nov. isolated from a marine sponge of the genus Haliclona and description of the family Endozoicomonadaceae fam. nov. comprising the genera Endozoicomonas, Parendozoicomonas, and Kistimonas ଝ

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Bacteria of the genus Endozoicomonas are marine bacteria which occur globally distributed as symbiotic microbes associated with different marine eukaryotic organisms. Bacterial symbionts of eukaryotic hosts are of particular interest due to the fact that they produce toxins, signaling molecules, and other secondary metabolites important for the interaction and defense of the eukaryotic hosts [1,15,55]. The genus Endozoicomonas was proposed by Kurahashi and Yokota [35] and emended by Nishijima et al. [44] and https://doi.org/10.1016/j.syapm.2017.11.004 0723-2020/© 2017 Elsevier GmbH. All rights reserved.

Pike et al. [45]. It belongs to the order Oceanospirillales [20] of the class Gammaproteobacteria. Bacteria of the genus stain Gramnegative, are rod-shaped, motile or non-motile and form beige colored colonies on marine agar (MA). Cells are oxidase and catalase positive. Sodium chloride is required for growth. Cells grow aerobically and partially anaerobically with energy generation often by carbohydrate fermentation. The major ubiquinone system is Q-9. The major cellular fatty acids are C 16:1 7c, C 16:0 , C 14:0 and C 18:1 7c and the major hydroxyl fatty acids are C 14:0 3-OH, C 10:0 3-OH, and C 12:0 3-OH. The DNA G + C content is 46.7-50.4 mol%.

All species of the genus Endozoicomonas were isolated from marine invertebrates such as sponges [44,4], corals [66,45,54], bivalves [28], gastropods [35], or ascidians [52]. Currently, nine Endozoicomonas species are described, Endozoicomonas arenosclerae [4], Endozoicomonas ascidiicola [52], Endozoicomonas atrinae [28], Endozoicomonas elysicola (type species) [35], Endozoicomonas euniceicola and Endozoicomonas gorgoniicola (both [45]), Endozoicomonas montiporae [66], and Endozoicomonas numazuensis [44], and just recently, Endozoicomonas acroporae [54]. Using cultivation independent methods, it was shown that members of the genus Endozoicomonas are predominant in various marine eukaryotic hosts [6,40] and seem to play an important role for nutrient acquisition and provision, the structuring of the host microbiome and the health status of the host holobiont [43,4,64,29].

Based on the 16S rRNA gene sequence phylogeny the closest relative of the genus Endozoicomonas is Candidatus Endonucleobacter bathymodioli, a bacterial parasite that can invade and multiply in the nucleus of bathymodiolin mussels. It was found in six bathymodiolin species all around the world, but representative strains have not been isolated so far [70]. The next related genus with cultured representative is Kistimonas, which comprised two species both isolated from eukaryotic hosts [13,39]. The genus Endozoicomonas is placed phylogenetically within the order Oceanospirillales [20]. The assignment at the family level is however controversially discussed. Several publications listed the genus Endozoicomonas as a member of the family Hahellaceae [13,45,52,27,54], but, as already pointed out by Kurahashi and Yokota [35] and shown in subsequent studies [13,44], in phylogenetic trees based on 16S rRNA gene sequences, type strains of the genus Endozoicomonas clustered with Kistimonas and partially with the genus Zooshikella [68], and not with type strains of the genus Hahella, the type genus of the family Hahellaceae [19].

Based on the application of a polyphasic taxonomic approach, including a detailed phylogenomic approach, we propose here a novel genus, Parendozoicomonas gen. nov., a sister genus to the genus Endozoicomonas with the type species Parendozoicomonas haliclonae gen. nov. sp. nov., with two bacterial strains, S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a, isolated from the internal compartment of a marine sponge of the genus Haliclona during high throughput cultivation of sponge-associated bacteria. In addition, we performed a detailed analysis for the phylogenetic placement of the genera Endozoicomonas and Parendozoicomonas within the Oceanospirillales and propose the family Endozoicomonadaceae fam. nov. comprising the genera Endozoicomonas, Parendozoicomonas, Kistimonas, and Cand. E. bathymodioli.

div.head: Isolation and reference strains
div.p: Strains S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a were isolated from a marine sponge of the genus Haliclona, which has been maricultured since 2001 in the CEMarin aquarium facilities at Justus-Liebig-University Giessen, Germany (50 • 34 08 N and 8 • 40 22 E). Sponge material was rinsed with autoclaved pure water to remove loosely attached bacteria, cut in small pieces with a sterile scalpel and homogenized with a sterile mortar in 10 mL autoclaved and 0.22 m-filter sterilized ambient water from the aquaria system. The suspension was centrifuged at 1270 g for 10 min at room temperature and the bacterial suspension in the supernatant was used for cultivation. First, 100 L of the suspension was directly plated on marine agar (MA; including 40.1 g L −1 marine broth MB, Carl Roth, adjusted to pH 8.0 and solidified with 15 g L −1 agar). The agar plate was incubated for 7 days at 25 • C in the dark and grown colonies were purified by repeated streaking on MA at 25 • C. Second, 20 L of the supernatant was used as inoculum for a dilution-to-extinction enrichment cultivation [12] in a microtiter plate by a serial dilution in marine broth (MB) (total volume: 200 L). After 2 months of incubation at 25 • C in the dark subsamples (10 L) of the enrichment cultures from the highest dilution (10 −8 ) were streaked on MA at 25 • C for 48 h. Grown colonies were purified as described above. Strain S-B4-1U T was isolated from the first, JOB-63a from the second cultivation approach. The strains were maintained at 4 • C for several weeks. For long-term storage, cultures grown on MA at 25 • C for 2-3 days were suspended in newborn calf serum (NBCS, Gibco/Life Technologies) in Micronic tubes and stored at −20 • C.

div.head: Phylogenetic analyses
div.p: The nearly full-length 16S rRNA genes of both strains were sequenced for phylogenetic analysis. Cell lysates were generated from a loop of biomass suspended in sterile, pyrogen free, and hypotonic water (Roth) which was exposed to three freezing (−20 • C) and thawing (1 min, 100 • C) cycles. The 16S rRNA gene was PCR-amplified from the cell lysates using primers 8F (5 -AGAGTTTGATCCTGGCTCAG-3 ) and 1492R (5 -ACGGCTACCTTGTTACGACTT-3 ) [36] according to Ref. Schauss et al. [51] and subsequently sequenced with the Sanger method using primers 27F (5 -GAGTTTGATCMTGGCTCAG-3 ) and E786F (5 -GATTAGATACCCTGGTAG-3 ) by LGC Genomics (Berlin, Germany). MEGA 5.2.1 [59] was used to process the obtained sequences. Ambiguous positions at the 5 and 3 ends of the sequences were removed and partial sequences were merged based on the overlapping sequence regions. The EzBioCloud identifier was used for initial phylogenetic identification by the determination of the 16S rRNA gene sequence similarity to the next related type strains [69].

Detailed phylogenetic analyses were performed in ARB release 5.2 [41] using the LTPs128 (February 2017) database of the "All species living tree project" (LTPs) [67]. The 16S rRNA gene sequences of strains S-B4-1U T , JOB-63a, and further reference sequences not included in the database were aligned with the SILVA Incremental Aligner (SINA v1.2.11) [47] and added to the LTP database tree without changing the overall tree topology. The alignment including all members of the order Oceanospirillales was checked manually before further analysis considering the secondary structure of the 16S rRNA. Type strains of species of the genus Legionella were included in the analysis to function as outgroup for phylogenetic tree constructions. Pairwise sequence similarities were calculated with the ARB neighbor-joining tool, without using evolutionary models. Phylogenetic trees were constructed with the maximum-likelihood (ML) method using RAxML v7.04 [57] with GTR-GAMMA and rapid bootstrap analysis, the maximum-parsimony (MP) method using DNAPARS v3.6 [18], and the neighbor-joining (NJ) methods using ARB neighbor-joining and the Jukes-Cantor correction [30]. All phylogenetic trees based on 100 re-samplings (bootstrap analysis) [16] and 16S rRNA gene sequences between gene termini 55 and 1455 (according to the Escherichia coli rrnB numbering) [9]. Phylogenetic trees were either calculated without a conservatory filter, the 30% conservatory filter of the LTPs128 database or a 30% conservatory filter calculated for members of the Oceanospirillales in the LTPs128 database. Tree topologies were compared among each other and to the topologies in the phylogenetic trees provided by the LTP databased version 123 and LTPs128, respectively. A consensus tree based of ML, MP, and NJ trees calculated with and without the 30% Oceanospirillales conservatory filter was calculated subsequently. Due to the specific ecological niche of Endozoicomonas spp. (symbionts of marine eukaryotic hosts) a subsequent phylogenetic analysis was performed in ARB including environmental full-length Endozoicomonas related 16S rRNA gene sequences obtained from different sponges and corals. A respective ARB database including those environmental 16S rRNA gene sequences was generated previously by Ref. Simister et al. [56]. The 16S rRNA gene sequences of the novel strains and Endozoicomonas and Kistimonas type strains were aligned and added to the database as described above. The alignment including those sequences and the nearly full-length environmental sequences were checked manually and sequence position spanning gene termini 84-1391 were used for phylogenetic analyses performed as described above.

div.head: Further genotypic differentiation of strains S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a
div.p: For DNA-DNA hybridization (DDH) and investigation of the genomic DNA G + C contents of strains S-B4-1U T , JOB-63a, and E. elysicola DSM 22380 T , high molecular weight genomic DNA was extracted according to Pitcher and Saunder [46]. The pairwise genomic relatedness (DDH analysis) of strains S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a was investigated as described by Ziemke et al. [71]. The genomic DNA G + C content was determined by the DNA melting temperature methods established by Gonzales and Saiz-Jimenez [24] as described previously [22].

According to Glaeser et al. [23] genotypic differentiation of strains S-B4-1U T , JOB-63a, and the reference strain E. elysicola DSM 22380 T was performed using cell lysates as template and three repetitive element primed (rep)-PCRs, BOX-PCR with primer BOX A1R (5 -CTA CGG CAA GGC GAC GCT GACG-3 ), (GTG) 5 -PCR using primer (GTG) 5 (5 -GTG GTG GTG GTG GTG-3 ) [63], and ERIC-PCR using primers ERIC 1R (5 -ATG TAA GCT CCT GGG GAT TCAC-3 ) and ERIC 2 (5 -AAG TAA GTG ACT GGG GTG AGCG-3 ) [62]. In contrast to the original method [23] 0.02 U L −1 DreamTaq DNA polymerase was applied and the elongation time for the (GTG) 5 -PCR was increased from 3 to 8 min. Genomic fingerprint patterns were compared in GelCompar II (AppliedMath) by cluster analysis performed with the Unweighted Pair Group Method with Arithmetic mean (UPGMA) method based on a similarity matrix calculated with the Pearson correlation.

div.head: Genome based phylogenetic analysis
div.p: A whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequence of strain S-B4-1U T was generated from DNA extracted with the MasterPure DNA purification kit (Epicentre). A library for short-read sequencing was generated using the Nextera XT DNA Library Prep Kit with 1 ng of whole genomic DNA and following the manufacturers' instructions for library preparation (Illumina). Whole genome sequencing was carried out by paired-end sequencing on a MiSeq benchtop instrument (Illumina) with 2 × 300 bp final read length. The assembly was performed with the Geneious 10.0.5 assembler using default settings and annotated.

A core genome based phylogenetic tree was constructed using the EDGAR 2.0 platform [8]. Briefly, the core genome was calculated using the implemented function of EDGAR. Multiple alignments of core genes were generated using MUSCLE [14]. The alignments of the remaining gene set were concatenated to one large multiple alignment which was used as input file for phylogenetic tree construction in PHYLIP [17]. Distance matrices were calculated with the evolutionary models F84 (nucleotide sequences) or Kimura (amino acid sequences) and phylogenetic trees (nucleic acid and amino acid sequence based) were calculated with the NJ method as implemented in PHYLIP. Twelve genome sequences were included in the analysis. Genome sequences of all type strains of the genera Endozoicomonas, Hahella, Pseudohongiella, and Alcanivorax (outgroup) available at GenBank were integrated in the phylogenetic tree construction. A total of 42,990 protein-coding sequences (CDS) (1433 per genome) and 15,368,550 amino acid residues (512,285 per genome) were finally included in the analysis.

Average nucleotide identities (ANIs) [34] and average amino acid identities (AAIs) [33] were calculated using the EDGAR 2.0 platform. The ANIs between the genome sequence of strain S-B4-1U T and the other 12 genome sequences were calculated as the mean identity of all BLASTN matches that showed more than 30% overall sequence identity over any alignable region of at least 70% of their length [25]. For AAI analysis, the conserved genes in the genomes of 11 type strain (excluding the outgroup, see above) were determined by whole-genome sequence comparisons using the BLAST algorithm [3].

div.head: Physiological characterization
div.p: For the phenotypic characterization strains S-B4-1U T , JOB-63a, and E. elysicola DSM 22380 T were cultured on MA for 2-3 days at 25 • C. Anaerobic growth was tested on MA using Anaerocult A pads (Merck) at 25 • C for 7 days. Gram-staining was performed by the modified Hucker method according to Gerhardt et al. [21].

Cell morphology was determined by light microscopy at 1000fold magnification using a Leica DM5000B microscope (Leica Microsystems) and slides coated with 2% autoclaved washed agar. The LASX 1.5.1.13187 (Leica Microsystems) software was used for cell size measurements. Cell morphology of strain S-B4-1U T was additionally studied using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Cells grown for 2 days in MB at 25 • C were centrifuged at 82 g for 10 min and suspended in 0.05 M cacodylate buffer (CB, pH 7.2). After repeated centrifugation and removal of the supernatant, cells were fixed overnight at 4 • C in 0.05 M CB containing 2.5% glutaraldehyde (GD) and 1.5% paraformaldehyde (PF). Fixed cells were attached to sterile, glow discharged, and poly-l-lysin coated glass cover slides by sedimentation for 30 min. Attached cells were again fixed for 20 min in 0.05 M CB with GD and PF and washed twice in 0.05 M CB for 10 min. CB was exchanged by 0.05 M CB containing 1% osmium for post fixation. Samples were placed on a rotary shaker at 75 rpm for 90 min and then washed again twice, first in 0.05 M CB and then in double distilled water. Cells were contrasted with 4% uranyl acetate overnight at 4 • C and thereafter washed twice with double distilled water and placed on ice on a rotary shaker at 75 rpm for 10 min. After dehydration through a graded ethanol series samples were subjected to supercritical drying in a CPD 030 (Balzers), N650 planocarbon (Plano GmbH) was applied to slides and cells were gold sputtered in a SCD 004 (Balzers) for 25 s. Samples were inspected by scanning electron microscopy (accelerating voltage 3 kV).

Cytochrome C oxidase activity was tested with Microbiology Bactident oxidase test stripes (Merck) and catalase activity by the formation of gas bubbles after dropping 3% (w/v) H 2 O 2 onto a fresh culture grown on MA. The presence of flexirubin type pigment was tested with the KOH method according to Reichenbach [48]. Substrate degradation activity was tested with MA supplemented with Growth on different agar media and temperature-dependent growth were tested with spot assay experiments. A loop of fresh biomass (5 days old) was suspended in 75% (w/v) autoclaved ASW to a density of a McFarland 0.5 standard [42]. The cell suspension was serially diluted up to 10 −4 and 5 L of each dilution was spotted on agar plates and growth was monitored after 1, 2, 5, , and pHdependent growth was tested using MB adjusted to pH values of pH 4.5-11.0 (in 0.5 pH unit intervals until pH 9, in 1 pH unit intervals from pH 9 to 11). The pH values were adjusted using 1 M HCl and 1 M KOH and stabilized by the addition of 5 mM autoclaved potassium phosphate buffer (pH values 4.5-7.5), 5 mM autoclaved Tris-HCl buffer (pH values 8-9) and 5 mM autoclaved CAPS buffer (pH value 11) adjusted to the same pH values as the MB medium. Salinity and pH-dependent growth was investigated in 96-well microtiter plates with a final volume of 200 L. Further physiological tests were performed using the API 20 NE, API 50 CH, API ZYM test stripes (bioMérieux) and the 96-well plate physiological test panel according to Kämpfer et al. [31]. API tests were performed as described by the manufacturerís instruction except, for inoculation of API 20 NE and API ZYM, four days old bacterial colonies were suspended in 75% autoclaved ASW to McFarland 0.5 and 6.0, respectively. For API 50 CH, a loop of fresh biomass was suspended in 1 mL of 75% autoclaved ASW to McFarland 4 and added to a tube of API 50 CHB/E medium for inoculation of the test panels. The API ZYM panel was analyzed after four hours. API 50 CH and API 20 NE were analyzed after three days of incubation at 25 • C, except for nitrate reduction and indole production (API 20 NE), which were analyzed after 48 h. For the inoculation of the physiological tests according to Kämpfer et al. [31] biomass was suspended in 75% autoclaved ASW to a McFarland value of 0.5. Analyses were performed after three days of growth at 25 • C. All physiological tests were conducted in parallel with strain S-B4-1U T , JOB-63a, and E. elysicola DSM 22380 T .

div.head: Chemotaxonomic analyses
div.p: Biomass for cellular fatty acid analysis was harvested after 2 days of growth at 25 • C on MA (late exponential growth phase). Fatty acid extraction and analysis was performed according to Kämpfer and Kroppenstedt [32] by the separation of fatty acid methyl ester by gas chromatography (5898A, Hewlett Packard). Peaks were automatically integrated and fatty acid names and percentages were determined with the Sherlock MIDI version 2.1 (TSBA version 4.1).

Biomass subjected to analyses of the peptidoglycan diamino acid, polyamines, quinones and polar lipids was grown in PYE broth (w/v; 0.3% peptone from casein, 0.3% yeast extract, pH 7.2) supplemented with 3% (w/v) Marine Sea Salt (w/v Tetra, Melle, Germany). Biomass used to extract polyamines was harvested at the late exponential growth phase as recommended by Busse and Auling [10]. For the other analyses, biomass was harvested at the stationary growth phase. Polyamines were extracted as reported recently [10] and analyzed according to the conditions suggested by Busse et al. [11]. The HPLC equipment was described by Stolz et al. [58]. Quinones and polar lipids were extracted following the integrated method reported by Tindall [60,61] and Altenburger et al. [2]. Identification of diaminopimelic acid was carried out following the protocol of Schumann [53].

div.head: Results
div.p: Phylogenetic affiliation of the novel strains based on 16S rRNA gene sequence phylogeny

The sequenced nearly full-length 16S rRNA gene of the two isolates, S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a, represented continuous stretches of 1447 and 1436 nucleotides spanning gene termini 56-1503 and 56-1492, respectively (according to the E. coli rrnB numbering) [9]. The two isolates shared 99.7% 16S rRNA gene sequence similarity. A first phylogenetic placement using the EzBioCloud identifier showed that the isolates shared highest 16S rRNA gene sequence similarities with E. numazuensis DSM 25634 T (94.1% and 94.3%). Detailed 16S rRNA gene sequence based phylogenetic analyses were performed including members of six families of the order Oceanospirillales (Gammaproteobacteria). The two novel isolates formed a distinct sister group next to the monophyletic cluster of the genus Endozoicomonas. Next closest related genera were Cand. Endonucleobacter and Kistimonas. A consensus tree constructed based on ML, MP, and NJ trees calculated with and without conservatory filters is depicted in Fig. 1.

Independent of the applied treeing method and with or without the application of different conservative filters the genera Endozoicomonas together with the branch of the novel strains, Cand. Endonucleobacter, and Kistimonas formed a monophyletic cluster supported by high bootstrap value (Fig. 1). In most of the calculated phylogenetic trees a branch containing the two type strains of the genus Zooshikella was placed next to that cluster. This relationship was, however, not supported by high bootstrap values. As already shown in previous studies the position of the genus Zooshikella in the phylogenetic trees varied. Partially Zooshikella type strains clustered with other members of the Oceanospirillales including the genus Hahella [5,27,44]. A direct clustering of the genera Endozoicomonas and Kistimonas with members of the genus Hahella was not observed in any of the phylogenetic trees.

The two novel strains, S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a, shared 92.3-94.1% and 92.5-94.3% pairwise 16S rRNA sequence similarities to the type strains of the genus Endozoicomonas followed by 91.9 and 92.1% to the representative sequence of Cand. Endonucleobacter bathymodioli and 91.1-91.7% and 91.3-91.9% sequence similarity with the type strains of the genus Kistimonas. Sequence similarities to all other members of the Oceanospirillales were much lower. All sequence similarities of the novel isolates to next related species, including those of the genus Endozoicomonas, were below the taxonomic threshold of 94.9 (+/−0.4) % proposed by Yarza et al. [67] for the differentiation of genera.

More detailed phylogenetic analyses in an ecological relevant context were performed by the inclusion of environmental 16S rRNA gene sequences of not yet cultured Endozoicomonas related sponge and coral associated bacteria. The performed analysis was based on the study of Simister et al. [56]. Phylogenetic trees calculated with different treeing methods showed that the two novel isolates formed a distinct cluster with few environmental 16S rRNA gene sequences, which were clearly separated from genus Endozoicomonas (Fig. A.1). The cluster was supported by a high bootstrap value. This phylogenetic analysis further confirmed the phylogenetic distinction of the isolates S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a from members of the genus Endozoicomonas.

div.head: Genotypic differentiation of strains S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a
div.p: DNA-DNA hybridization values of the cross hybridization of the two isolates, S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a, were around 100%. Consider-ing the species boundary of 70% DNA-DNA relatedness [65], the two isolates belong to the same species. Differences in the genomic fingerprint patterns obtained by the three rep-PCRs indicated, that the two isolates were genetically different and represent therefore two different strains of one species (Fig. 2a-c). UPGMA clustering based on the genetic fingerprint patterns showed that the two novel strains were genomically closer related to each other com- pared to E. elysicola DSM 22380 T , which always clustered separately ( Fig. 2a-c).

The genomic DNA G + C content of strains S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a was 50.1 and 51.4 mol%, and therefore slightly different from each other. The G + C content was in the same range as the G + C content reported for type strains of Endozoicomonas species (46.7-50.4 mol%, [4,28,35,44,52,66]). The G + C content of E. elysicola DSM 22380 T was analyzed in parallel and the same G + C content was obtained as given in the original publication [35]. Furthermore, the G + C content of strain S-B4-1U T investigated via DNA melting temperature was confirmed by the G + C content obtained from the genome sequence.

div.head: Genome based phylogenetic analysis
div.p: A total of 1,421,729 paired-end reads were generated for strain S-B4-1U T . The reads were assembled in 69 contigs (FWPT01000001-FWPT01000069). All contigs were larger than 355 bp. The largest contig had a size of 702,795 bp. The estimated genome size (based on the draft genome sequence) was 5.46 Mb. A total of 4,858 genes and among those 4,632 protein coding genes were predicted. The size of the genome and gene content was similar to the genomes of Endozoicomonas spp. type strains (Table 1).

In core genome based phylogenetic trees based on nucleotide ( Fig. 3a) and amino acid sequences (Fig. 3b) strain S-B4-1U T formed a separate branch next to the monophyletic cluster including the type strains of the genus Endozoicomonas. The tree topologies were validated by 250 bootstrapping iterations, which revealed 100% branch support on all branches.

Hierarchical clustering based on ANI (Fig. 4a) and AAI values (Fig. 4b) confirmed this phylogenetic placement. Based on both cluster analysis strain S-B4-1U T was placed as a separate branch next to a cluster including all type strains of the genus Endozoicomonas.

Strain S-B4-1U T shared ANI and AAI values with type strains of the genus Endozoicomonas in the range of 68.14-69.04% (ANI) and 68.48-69.2% (AAI), respectively ( Fig. 4a and b). Both, ANI and AAI values to type strains of the genera Hahella and Pseudohongiella were lower (Fig. 4a and b). Endozoicomonas type strains shared ANI and AAI values among each other in the range of 69.77-83.47% (ANI) and 75.35-93.49% (AAI), respectively. All ANI and AAI values obtained for strain S-B4-1U T to genomes of next related type strain were far below the ANI/AAI cut-off values proposed to define the species boundary [49]. In addition, both ANI and AAI values were below the values of 74.8% (ANI) and 87.8% (AAI), which were suggested recently by Sangal et al. [50] as genus threshold values.

div.head: Morphological and physiological characterization
div.p: Strains S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a formed small whitishtransparent, circular and convex colonies with a shiny surface on MA agar after two days of growth at 25 • C (Fig. 5a). The pigmentation of the colonies turned into orange after extended incubation of approximately seven days. Gram-stain-negative rod-shaped cells of strains S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a had a mean size of 2.5 ± 1.4 m and 3.7 ± 1.1 m in length and 0.8 ± 0.2 m in width after four days of growth on MA at 25 • C ( Fig. 5b and c; Fig. A.2a-c). Cells of strain JOB-63a were always slightly longer than those of strain S-B4-1U T . Good growth occurred for both strains aerobically at 21-37 • C with an optimum at 25-30 • C, reduced growth at 8-15 • C and no growth at 4 • C or less and 45 • C and above. Anaerobic growth was confirmed for S-B4-1U T and even stronger anaerobic growth obtained for JOB-63a after 5 days of incubation at 25 • C. In contrast, E. elysicola DSM 22380 T did not grow under anaerobic conditions. The novel strains grew only well on MA and Columbia agar with sheep blood, but not on R2A, NU, TS, Malt, G/A, PYE, CASO, K7, M65, DEV, NA, LB, and McConkey. In contrast to the novel strains, E. elysicola DSM 22380 T showed also reduced growth on CASO agar. Strain S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a grew only in the presence of NaCl. Salinity, pH and temperature dependent growth was identical for both strains (Table 1). Physiological tests performed with different test panels showed very similar results for the compared strains. Except, in the enzyme activity test, no N-acetyl-beta-glucosaminidase and pNP-␤-d-galactopyranosidase activities were obtained for strain S-B4-1U T , but for JOB-63a and E. elysicola DSM 22380 T . Strain JOB-63a showed also activity for the hydrolysis of pNP-phosphoryl-choline. The E. elysicola type strain differed from S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a in the production of acids from myo-inositol and potassium 5-ketogluconate. Results of the physiological test panel according to Kämpfer et al. [31] showed differences in 22 of 55 carbon source assimilation tests. DNase test showed a clearance zone for S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a, but not for E. elysicola DSM 22380 T . All physiological properties of the novel strains are provided in the species description. Physiological characteristics of strains S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a compared to E. elysicola DSM 22380 T and other Endozoicomonas type strains are summarized in Table 1.

div.head: Chemotaxonomic characterization
div.p: Cellular fatty acid profiles of strains S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a contained major amounts of summed feature 3 (C 16:1 7c/C 16:1 6c) and summed feature 8 (C 18:1 7c/C 18:1 6c), moderate amounts of C 16:0 and low amounts of C 10:0 3-OH, C 14:0 and C 18:0 . Low amounts of summed feature 2 (C 14:0 3-OH/iso C 16:1 ), C 18:1 9c and 10- Table 1 Comparison of morphological, physiological and molecular properties between strains S-B4-1U T , JOB-63a, and type strain of Endozoicomonas and Kistimonas species (all members of the proposed family Endozoicomonadaceae).

div.head: Fig. 3.
div.p: Core genome phylogenetic trees based on nucleotide (a) and amino acid (b) sequences showing the phylogenetic relationship of strain S-B4-1U T to type strains of the genus Endozoicomonas and related genera. Phylogenetic trees were constructed with the NJ method using the EDGAR 2.0 platform [8]. Multiple alignments of core genes were generated using MUSCLE [14]. A total of 42,990 CDS (1,433 per genome) and 15,368,550 amino acid residues (512,285 per genome) were finally included in the analysis. The genome sequence of Alcanivorax pacificus W11-5 T was used as outgroup.

methyl C 19:0 were only detected for S-B4-1U T , but not for JOB-63a. The fatty acid profiles were similar to those described for the genus Endozoicomonas [35,44,45], except the commonly detected second hydroxyl fatty acid C 12:0 3-OH was not detected for strains S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a. C 18:1 9c and 10-methyl C 19:0 were only detected for strain S-B4-1U T , but not for JOB-63a and none of the Endozoicomonas type strains. The comparison of the fatty acid profile of strain S-B4-1U T , JOB-63a, and Endozoicomonas and Kistimonas type strains are given in Table 2. Fatty acid patterns of both genera were concordant with respect to the predominant fatty acids and showed significant differences to the fatty acid pattern described for the genera Hahella [37] and Allohahella [27], which contained C 18:1 9c as major fatty acid, which is not or only in very low abundance present in the fatty acid profiles of the genera Endozoicomonas and Kistimonas. In addition, among minor abundant fatty acids (around 5%) the fatty acids C 16:0 N alcohol, C 16:1 9c, and C 18:3 6c occurred in the fatty acid profiles of Hahella and Allohahella, but not in those of Endozoicomonas and Kistimonas. In contrast, the 3-hydroxyl fatty acid C 10:0 3-OH occurred only in the genera Endozoicomonas and Kistimonas.

The ubiquinone system was only investigated for strain S-B4-1U T and resulted in ubiquinone Q-9 (95.6%) with small amounts of Q-8 (4.1%) and Q-10 (0.3%), which is in line with those reported for Endozoicomonas species [35,43,45,66]. However, Q-10 was not reported for those. The polar lipid profile (Fig. 6) is composed of the major compounds phosphatidylethanolamine (PE), phosphatidylglycerol (PG), and phosphatidylserine (PS), moderate to minor amounts of diphosphatidylglycerol (DPG), unidentified phospholipid (PL), aminolipid (AL1) and two lipids (L1, L2), which are only visible after staining for total lipids. This polar lipid profile is highly similar to those reported for type strains of E. acroporae [54], E. ascidiicola [45], E. atrinae [28,54], E. elysicola [28], E. euniceicola [54], and E. numazuensis [54]. Phosphatidylserine was not reported for those type strains, but the comparison of the lipid profiles on thin layer chromatography (TLC) plate shown in the respective publication indicated that APL1 (in Refs. [28,54]) and the unidentified phosphoaminolipid (PN) (in Ref. [52]) represent PS. The polyamine pattern of strain S-B4-1U T contained the major compound spermidine [8.8 mol (g dry weight) −1 ] and traces [<0.2 mol (g dry weight) −1 ] of putrescine, cadaverine, symhomospermidine and spermine. Unfortunately, no polyamine patterns have been analyzed for any closely related species of the genus Endozoicomonas. But the more distantly-related species Marinobacter hydrocarboniclasticus shows a polyamine pattern with the major compound spermidine [26]. This observation suggests that all members of this group are characterized by polyamine patterns with the major polyamine spermidine. The diagnostic diamino acid of the peptidoglycan is meso-diaminopimelic acid.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Based on the 16S rRNA gene sequence phylogeny and phylogenomic analyses, strains S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a are placed in a distinct sister group closely related to but distinct from the genus Endozoicomonas. Taxonomic thresholds based on 16S rRNA gene sequence similarities and ANI/AAI indices indicated that the novel strains represent a novel genus. A clear distinction based on physiological, biochemical, and chemotaxonomic data to the genera Endozoicomonas but also Kistimonas could not be given (Tables 1 and 2). But due to the clear genotypic distinction, it is indicated that strains S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a represent a novel species within a novel genus with the proposed name Parendozoicomonas gen. nov., and the novel species P. haliclonae sp. nov. with strain S-B4-1U T (=CCM 8713 T = DSM 103671 T = LMG 29769 T ) as type strain. Strain JOB-63a represent as second strain of the species (confirmed by DDH), which could be differentiated from the type strain by genomic fingerprinting using rep-PCRs, few physiological properties and slight morphological differences.

Based on the formation of a stable and distinct (bootstrap value >90%) monophyletic cluster of the genera Endozoicomonas, Parendozoicomonas, Cand. Endonucleobacter, and Kistimonas in the 16S rRNA gene sequence based phylogenetic trees, it is justified that these genera should be placed in one family. This family is clearly separated from the Hahellaceae (Fig. 1). Members of the above listed genera also share the same habitat, eukaryotic marine hosts. The next related genus that clustered to those genera was the genus Zooshikella. However, that clustering was not consistent in all treeing methods and not supported by high bootstrap values (always <30%). In addition, members of the genus Zooshikella as well as Hahella and Allohahella (both members of the Hahellaceae) were isolated form different marine niches (non-host associated) which supported the distinction to members of the genera Endozoicomonas, Parendozoicomonas, and Kistimonas [5,7,27,37,38,68]. Cells stain Gram-negative, are rod-shaped and motile. Chemoorganotrophic growth, both aerobically and anaerobically. Sodium chloride (at least 0.5% w/v NaCl) is required for growth.

The fatty acid profile of total cell hydrolysates consists mainly of summed feature 3 (C 16:1 7c/C 16:1 6c), summed feature 8 (C 18:1 7c/C 18:1 6c) and lower amounts of C 16:0 , C 10:0 3-OH, C 18:0 , C 18:1 9c, C 14:0 , summed feature 2 (C 14:0 3-OH/iso C 16:1 ), and 10methyl C 19:0 . The ubiquinone system is ubiquinone Q-9 with small amounts of Q-8 and Q-10. Polar lipids comprise the major compounds PE, PG, and PS, and moderate amounts of DPG. Minor amounts of further unidentified PLs, AL, and lipids, which are only visible after staining for total lipids. The polyamine pattern comprises the major compound spermidine and traces of putrescine, cadaverine, sym-homospermidine and spermine. The diagnostic diamino acid of the peptidoglycan is meso-diaminopimelic acid. The genomic G + C content is in the range of 50.1 and 51.4 mol%. The genus represents a sister genus to the genus Endozoicomonas within the Gammaproteobacteria. It is clearly separated based on the 16S rRNA gene and core genome based phylogeny from the genus Endozoicomonas. The type species is P. haliclonae. The Taxonumber of the genus is GA00044. Table 2 Fatty acid composition of strains S-B4-1U T , JOB-63a, and type strains of Endozoicomonas and Kistimonas species (all members of the porposed family Endozoicomonadaceae). Strains 1-3 were investigated in parallel in this study. Values in brackets were obtained from Kurahashi and Yokota [35]. Strains were grown on MA at 25 • C, except E. atrinae DSM 100061 T and E. acroporae Acr-14 T were grown at 30 • C; E. euniceicola DSM 26535 T and E. gorgoniicola NCCB 100438 T were cultured on NB supplemented with 3% NaCl at 22 • C, 3 days. Values show the percentage of the total fatty acids. a Summed feature 2 (C14:0 3-OH/iso C16:1); summed feature 3 (C16:1 7c/C16:1 6c); summed feature 8 (C18:1 7c/C18:1 6c). Negative for the hydrolysis of casein, starch, carboxymethylcellu-lose, Tween 20, Tween 40, Tween 60, and Tween 80 after three and seven days of incubation. Negative for the reduction of nitrate to nitrogen, glucose fermentation, arginine dihydrolase, urease, hydrolysis of gelatin, assimilation of glucose, arabinose, mannose, mannitol, N-acetyl-glucosamine, maltose, gluconate, caprate, adi-pate, malate, citrate and phenylacetate, but positive for reduction of nitrate to nitrite, indole production, hydrolysis of esculin and ␤-galactosidase (API 20 NE). Positive for enzyme activity of acid phosphatase, alkaline phosphatase, leucine arylamidase, trypsin, The type strain S-B4-1U T (= CCM 8713 T = DSM 103671 T = LMG 29769 T ) was isolated from the internal tissue of a marine sponge of the genus Haliclona, which was cultured in the CEMarin aquarium facilities at Justus-Liebig-University in Giessen, Germany. One further strain, JOB-63a isolated from the same habitat at the same time but grown in another cultivation approach, represents a second strain of the species which could be differentiated from the type strain by rep-PCR analysis. The genomic G + C content of the type strain is 50.1 mol% (T m method, genome sequence based). The taxonumber of the species is TA00209.

div.head: Emended. description of the genus Endozoicomonas
div.p: The description is that of Kurahashi and Yokota [35], Nishijima et al. [44], and Pike et al. [45] with the following emendments:
Major compounds of the polar lipid profile are PE, PG, and PS, moderate to minor amounts of DPG can be present. All species occur in association with marine eukaryotic organisms.
Description of Endozoicomonadaceae fam. nov.
Endozoicomonaceae (En.do.zoi.co.mo.na.daíceae. N.L. fem. n. Endozoicomonas type genus of the family; -aceae ending to denote a family; N.L. fem. pl. n. Endozoicomonaceae the Endozoicomonas family).

Gram-stain-negative, rod-shaped motile cells. Chemoorganotrophs. Aerobic and anaerobic growth. Require salts for growth, at least 0.5% (w/v) NaCl. Ubiquinone Q-9 is the major respiratory quinone. Phosphatidylethanolamine (PE), PG, PS, and DPG are present in the polar lipid pattern. Summed feature 3 (C 16:1 7c/C 16:1 6c) and C 16:0 are predominant fatty acids and C 10:0 3-OH as major hydroxyl fatty acid. The G + C of the genomic DNA is between 47 and 51 mol%.

Associated with eukaryotic hosts in marine habitats. On the basis of 16S rRNA gene sequence analyses, the family belongs within the class Gammaproteobacteria to the order Oceanospirillales. Members of the family are the genera Endozoicomonas, Parendozoicomonas, and Kistimonas. The type genus is Endozoicomonas.

For starch degradation, iodide solution (Lugolís solution) was spread over the colonies to determine the clearance zone. figure.head: Fig. 1 .
figure.figDesc: Phylogenetic tree based on nearly full-length 16S rRNA gene sequences showing the placement of strains S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a next to the genus Endozoicomonas within the Endozoicomonadaceae fam. nov. within the Oceanospirillales (Gammaproteobacteria). The phylogenetic tree represents a consensus tree of the ML, MP, and NJ trees calculated without and including a 30% conservator filter for the Oceanospirillales, in ARB. The analysis based on gene sequence termini 55 and 1,455 (numbering according to Brosius et al.[9]) and 100 replications (bootstrap support). Bootstrap values of 70% or above are depicted at nodes. Numbers within clusters represent the number of type strains included in the respective clusters. Type strains of Legionella species were used as outgroup. Scale bar: 0.1 substitutions per nucleotide positions.

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: Genomic fingerprint patterns differentiating strains S-B4-1U T and JOB-63a and the type strain of E. elysicola DSM 22380 T . Fingerprint patterns were generated with three rep-PCRs, BOX-PCR (a), (GTG)5-PCR (b), and ERIC-PCR (c). Cluster analyses based on ethidium bromide stained fingerprint patterns disolved on 1.4% agarose gels were performed in GelCompar II (Applied Maths) using the UPGMA clustering methods based on similarity matrices generated with the Pearson correlation coefficient.

Description of P. haliclonae sp. nov. P. haliclonae (ha.li.cloínae, pertaining to Haliclona, a sponge genus). In addition to the properties given in the genus description, the rod-shaped cells have a size of approximately 3.0 ± 2.0 m in length and 0.8 ± 0.2 m in width and colonies have a diameter of 1-2 mm and turn from transparent white to orange after 5-7 days. Growth occurs between 8 and 37 • C, optimal growth at 25 • C-30 • C. No growth is observed above 37 • C and below 8 • C. Good growth only
